member.summary: Gets access to common window related functions and global helper methods.
member.remarks: Wrapper information: This class implements IHTMLWindow2, IHTMLWindow3, and IHTMLWindow4.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Timer
member.summary: Gets access to timer features for smooth internal timed operations.
member.remarks: Wrapper information: This class partly implements IHTMLWindow2, IHTMLWindow3, and IHTMLWindow4.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsFrameDocument
member.summary: Gets true if the current document is a frame document.
member.remarks: The purpose of this property is to detect the frame state of the document and switch appropriate UI elements on or off. Internally the property simply checks the number of frames. Therefore the property may return false, even if the document is a frame document with just zero frames. Developery of application which use frames extensivly may double check the content using method and XPath to see the real content of the base document.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.HtmlFrames
member.summary: Returns an object containing all Frame information.

remarks.para: Works only if the base document of a frameset. If the document contains a body this getter is still active and usable, but the framecollection is null. After retrieving successfully the frame object it can used to manipulate or create framesets. If the current document is a standard document and a new frame structure is build, the content will depraved and replaced by a new empty frameset.
The documentation of for more information about manipulation framesets.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ContextMenu
member.summary: ContextMenu for the whole designer surface.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ContextMenuStrip
member.summary: ContextMenu for the whole designer surface.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.VerticalScrollPosition
member.summary: Gets the vertical scroll position.
member.remarks: The vertical scroll position is the distance from the document top to the current visible top border, measured in pixel. If the scrollbar is at the top position, this value is 0.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.HorizontalScrollPosition
member.summary: Gets the horizontal scroll position.
member.remarks: The horizontal scroll position is the distance from the document left to the current visible left border, measured in pixel. If the scrollbar is at the left position, this value is 0.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.AllowDrop
member.summary: Allow to use the NetRix control as a drop target.
member.remarks: Without this property the control will not recognize drop messages.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ActivationEnabled
member.summary: Gets/Sets if the control is active before receiving the focus.
member.remarks: The purpose of the property is to temporarily hook off the control from the TAB list of controls. This results in removing the cursor (insertion point) from surface, until the user explicitly clicks onto the surface. After this forced activation the control behaves like any other input control the property is no longer used.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsReady
member.summary: Indicates if the control is ready for use.

remarks.para: If the document was a frameset, the complete handling is done in HtmlFrameSet class. This class can set the IsReady property exclusivly to true, if the frame document is ready. This assures that subsequent calls / events used from the base classes, like work properly as they normally throw exceptions if methods are called for an unready document.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsDirty
member.summary: Indicates if the contents of the editor have been modified.
member.remarks:
This flag is set to false after a document or document fragment wss loaded. It becomes true after the first change in the documents structure or content. Moving the caret or clicking objects without moving them wil not set the flag to dirty state.
The flag will be reset on each save operation. This is done by calling the RawHtml content by any of the methods SaveHtml or SaveFormattedHtml. Whereas the SaveXXX methods really write content into a stream the GetRawHtml or GetFormattedHtml, method just returns the content to the caller. Both method are overloaded and provide a second parameter to force resetting the dirty flag. If this is done the host application should assure that the content is really saved, to keep the flag and the UI synchronized.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.InternalShortcutKeys
member.summary: Activates or deactivates the internal shortcut keys.
member.remarks:
If the property is on (default), the following keys are static assigned:
Key
Description
Design Mode Only
Ctrl-A
Select all
-
Ctrl-C
Copy selected text
-
Ctrl-P
Print immediately using internal dialogs.
-
Ctrl-U
Underline
+
Ctrl-B
Bold
+
Ctrl-I
Italic
+
Ctrl-L
Align Left (Block only)
+
Ctrl-R
Align Right (Block only)
+
Ctrl-J
Justify (Multiline Block only)
+
Ctrl-V
Paste
+
Ctrl-X
Cut
+
Ctrl-Y
Redo
+
Ctrl-Z
Undo
+
The property can be turned on and off during run time and will become active immediately.
To strip out specific keys you can handle the BeforeShortcut event and set the Cancel property to true to disable the internal key handling. The same event can be used to assign more Shortcut keys in your application, because the event is fired on every kex in combination with the Ctrl (Control) key, even if the key stroke is not handled elsewhere.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Encoding
member.summary: The encoding of the document.
member.remarks: The encoding can be changed during design time to change the document encoding with next save operation.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ScriptEnabled
member.summary: Does not execute any script until fully activated. Browse Mode only.
member.remarks:
NetRix does not execute any script until fully activated. This flag is used to postpone script execution until the host is active and, therefore, ready for script to be executed.
In design mode the scripting is always disabled and cannot be enabled by user code. When switching to browse mode or design mode to make scripting available remember to wait for event before issue any action or send commands.
Prior Version 1.6 the description was wrong, but the implemention was as intended.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ScrollBars
member.summary: Sets various styles regarding the scrollbars (runtime property only).
member.remarks:
This option sets the current body style to specific scrollbar options. To make this property persistent, the host application should either save the complete document, including the body, or save the body style "overflow" property separatly. The following table maps the various options against the CSS:
Property
CSS Style
None
hidden
ForcedBoth
scroll
Both
auto
Vertical, Horizontal, ForcedVertical, ForcedHorizontal
Not supported.
This property can set only after event has been fired.
This property is not accessible at design time, it can be set at runtime only.
The get accessor will return RichTextBoxScrollBars.Both in case of non recognizable value or non-existing attribute, which is the controls default behavior.
member.exception: Throws if the value cannot be transformed into corresponding CSS.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ScrollBarsEnabled
member.summary: Enables or disables scrollbars.
member.remarks:
This property works globally and turns scrollbars on or off for the next document being loaded. For more scrollbar options see property.
This property can be set at both, design time and run time.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.TempFile
member.summary: Allows access to the temp file if any exists, used for path resolvation.
member.remarks: The property may return null (Nothing in Visual Basic) in case of non existent temporary path.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.TempPath
member.summary: Allows access to the base path if any, used for path resolvation.
member.remarks: The property may return null (Nothing in Visual Basic) in case of non existent temporary path.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.AntiQuirks
member.summary: Sets the control into W3C compliant rendering mode.
member.remarks: This property changes the behavior of the document by setting the DOCTYPE tag on top of the document during creation. Existing documents will not change their behavior.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Url
member.summary: Gets the url of the document contained in the control.
member.remarks: If there is no path defined, the property returns null.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.HandleTAB
member.summary: Elements which could be influenced by TAB key should get TAB sequences in design mode.
member.remarks:
This applies to:
LI

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Border3d
member.summary: Show component borders in 3D style.
member.remarks: The default is true (3D style used). Changing this property requieres re-load.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.XPTheming
member.summary: Controls the way the component renders themeable controls.
member.remarks:
Buttons, Select boxes and other form elements can be rendered during design time using XP themes, if the application runs on XP. If the designer is used to design pages which run later on other operating systems, it is recommended to switch theming support of.
The default value is true (Theming is on).

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.BlockDefault
member.summary: Sets how paragraphs will be inserted, DIV or P tags.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.AllowInPlaceNavigation
member.summary: Set the behavior of links in browse mode.
member.remarks:
If this property is set to true an the user clicks a link in browse mode the new page will load internally and replace the current page. If set to false the link will start a new instance of Internet Explorer (or the systems default browser) and opens the link externally. Any further navigation operations are no longer under the control of NetRix.
This option is not recognized in design mode.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.NoTextSelection
member.summary: Disables the ability to select text if control is in browse mode.
member.remarks:
This applies only if the content is loaded after setting the property.
Note: This features is available as of NetRix Pro 1.6. It's not available in Advanced or Standard.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ImeReconversion
member.summary: Allows computer users to employ IME reconversion while browsing Web pages.
member.remarks:
During initialization, the host can set this flag to enable Input Method Editor (IME) reconversion, allowing computer users to employ IME reconversion while browsing Web pages. An input method editor is a program that allows users to enter complex characters and symbols, such as Japanese Kanji characters, using a standard keyboard.
Note: This features is available as of NetRix Pro 1.6.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsFullDocumentMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value to determine full document mode.
member.remarks:
The full document mode forces the basic structure of the loaded HTML document to this one:
<html> <body> <!-- your HTML fragment goes here --> </body> </html>
To avoid this behavior just set this property to false and reload the document.
Changing this property during an editing session will not be recognized.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanCopy
member.summary: Indicates if the current selection can be copied.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanCut
member.summary: Indicates if the current selection can be cut.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanPaste
member.summary: Indicates if the current selection can be pasted to.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanDelete
member.summary: Indicates if the current selection can be deleted.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanRedo
member.summary: Indicates if the editor can redo.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CanUndo
member.summary: Indicates if the editor can undo.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.FlatScrollBars
member.summary: Shows flat or normal themed scrollbars

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ThreadSafety
member.summary: Turns on thread safe access to properties and methods.
member.remarks: By default the component isn't thread safe. However, the burdensome Invoke technique required to invoke cross thread calls is implemented internally and can be turned on or off using this property. The drawback is that permanent access in a threadsafe manner could result in the performance flaw. In case nobody needs cross thread access it's recommended to let this property set to false.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsTrial
member.summary: Compiled as trial version.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CommandTarget
member.summary: Gets the command target to send IDM commands to the component.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.CurrentScopeElement
member.summary: Get the element near the last caret position. Does not recognize elements which have handles.
member.returns: The element

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.GenericElementFactory
member.summary: This property returns an instance of IElementFactory.
member.remarks: Its purpose is to provide access to the element factory for plug-ins and extension modules. Extension authors can use the factory to add elements to the elements cache. It's not recommended to use this property directly from user code, in fact, it supports the NetRix infrastructure only.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.UserAgent
member.summary: User Agent string used to identify the control when browsing the web.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Proxy
member.summary: Gets or sets the proxy used to support download beyond a proxy.
member.remarks: Set this property to null if no proxy is required. If the internal loader is being used the proxy settings of IE or operating system are bypassed. Restrictive security settings may make the operation fail, though.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.DocumentDom
member.summary: Returns the DOM (document object model) of the current loaded document.
member.remarks:
The property may return null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the document is either not ready or doesn't contain a HTML element.
After first call the reference to the object is being cached, so a direct and extensive access using this property does not cause a performance flaw. Any LoadXXX method will reset cache and the first subsequent call will recreate the new document structure. Changes to the document are reflected synchrounously.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.UseTempFile
member.summary: The tempfile option has been removed is no longer available. Obsolete.
member.remarks: Property returns always false.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.InnerHtml
member.summary: This property changes the content of the body.
member.remarks: Its purpose is to support simple databindings.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.InnerText
member.summary: This property changes the content of the body and strips out all HTML tags.
member.remarks:
This is for spellchecking and other basic text functions.
Setting this value will result in lost of all HTML based formatting, as the InnerText property internally strips out any HTML and does not preserve any formatting. Reading will not hurt the content.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ComplexContent
member.summary: Disables the internal monikers to support very complex content.
member.remarks: The internal moniker procedure helps building MHT and deals with local files faster. This handling may fail if complex documents, like the one exported by PowerPoint or Word are loaded.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.OuterHtml
member.summary: This property returns the document's content in raw (unformatted) format.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.EventManager
member.summary: Allows the management of events on element level.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.EventBinding
member.summary: Gets access to the event binding service.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.UIBinding
member.summary: Binding to the user interface service.
member.remarks:
The purpose is to have total control over the way designer aware components, like the PropertyGrid, operate and interact with the control and elements. This allows you to add component editors, catch internal errors thrown by the PropertyGrid, add styles or show private dialogs instead of the common one for collection editors or other internally invoked dialogs.
Several events can be used to interact with the service.
UIService IUIService (Netrix' implementation) IUIService (System's implementation)

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.Focused
member.summary: Informs whether the control has the focus.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.StopFocusOnLoad
member.summary: If set to true the focus will not set on load.
member.remarks:
The default behavior of the focus will set the focus on the control and activates the caret after loading a document or HTML. This property suppresses this behavior if set.
It is important to set (or let) this property to false, if content is loaded, which has client side scripts in it or which has forms where the user can enter values. If the document cannot receive the focus, the user cannot enter anything, the content is totally blocked.
The intention of this property is to allow the subsequential re-loading of the content using LoadHtml whereas the user enters data into another control on the form. If, under any circumstances, the user is allows to enter anything or copy anything from the control, the property must turned off (set to false again.
This property was introduced in the second edition of the 1016 Build, June 8, 2004. The normal behavior was not changed if the property is not set explicitly and the control runs in design mode. In browse mode the control runs with getting the focus, unless this property is explicitly set.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.TransposeEnterBehavior
member.summary: Exchanges the behavior of Enter key. If active, Enter inserts BR instead of P.
member.remarks: This method allows the editor to behave differently if the user hits the Enter key. By default, enter inserts a new paragraph. If this property is true, the Enter key will insert a break (BR tag). The opposite insertion method, Shft-Enter, will insert a paragraph. The type of paragraph depends on the the current setting.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.ChangeManager
member.summary: Allows access to the change monitor.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.IsFileBasedDocument
member.summary: Determines that the document is loaded from and saved into a file.
member.remarks: This property is set automatically if the document is loaded from an URL or file using the methods. If the LoadHtml methods are used, the host application can determine how the load/save process works. To work with files the property is set to true. This is the default value. To work without any file relation, the property should set to false, before issuing a LoadHtml method to load content.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.RegisteredPlugIns
member.summary: Gives direct access to the list of registered plug-ins.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlEditor.HtmlEditorSite
member.summary: Provides access for sited components.
member.remarks:
In case you work with a complete design time environment, including usage of PropertyGrid and services, the design time code needs access to the internal services the NetRix component provides. HtmlEditorSite gives that access by offering its own ISite implementation.
This is important, if you use the PropertyGrid to create new objects. For instance, if you have a <select> element and wish to add <option> elements, these elements need a reference to the underlying editor. The internal service is aware of this and the design time host is supposed to use these services as well.
The following examples assumes you have a PropertyGrid and HtmlEditor component on a form:
private void htmlEditor_HtmlElementChanged(object sender, HtmlElementChangedEventArgs e) { this.propertyGrid1.Site = htmlEditor.HtmlEditorSite; // comment out and ctor calls will fail! this.propertyGrid1.SelectedObject = e.CurrentElement; }
This assignes the internal Site to the PropertyGrid. And the grid will call the appropriate services, then.
Internally NetRix Pro provides a fully developed design time environment, which is responsible for all particular needs the HTML elements may have. Even if public constructors exists the call must match specific conditions to have valid references between the element and the editor.
In case you don't use the PropertyGrid you can cast HtmlEditorSite to ISite and use GetService to create elements within an design time environment. For instance, IDesignerHost ist available to create elements.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.ElementFactory
member.summary: This class wraps internal element objects into native one.
member.remarks:
This class is widely used internally to wrap the COM interface related element objects directly into .NET native objects. The class provides an object cache, which helds all previously created instances. The method CreateElement will call the internal constructor of each element class to instantiate the object.
Under normal circumstances a direct call to this classe is not appropriate. However, plug-ins may use the class to add there element types to the list of recognizable ones.

member.remarks: The element is recognized by alias and name, divided by colon (asp:button, html:img). The basic HTML elements have the alias html, even if the document loaded is not XHTML conform. For a HTML comment the name is "!" without an alias. Plug-Ins may define different name schemas.

The type defined in an assembly, which is part of the app domain.

So in any case an internal HTML element object is being retrieved, it's possible to cast to IElement instead. In case of a plug-in this is not required, because plug-ins may handle their elements differently and such a cast is not appropriate. member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Designer.CommandService
member.summary: Provides methods to manage the global designer verbs and menu commands available in design mode, and to show some types of shortcut menus.
member.remarks:
Provides support for commands and verbs. Verbs are opposite to properties and does not have any value one can set but instead provide method invoking. Though, the methods being invoked cannot have parameters. An good example of usage is the TableDesigner plugin. It exposes some commands like "AddRow", "DeleteColumn", or "RemoveCell". These commands are related to the current object and context and does not need any parameters. The way commands appear to the user depends on the host's user interface. The PropertyGrid will show them as links the ould click on. Implementers often add the commands to the context menu or extend parts of the main menu dynamically. This way the menu can show only valuable commands available for the current selection. The interface calls also the ContextMenu (and ContextMenuStrip) event. It does not provide any information about the menu itself. The latter is part of the user interface and not of NetRix. However, it provides the element which causes the menu being shown and from the element's Site property we have access to the services and the IMenuCommandService allows us to get the appropriate verbs. Adding verbs is done on several ways:
Using default verbs, implemented by NetRix. These verbs are available for all elements.
Add verbs globally by calling the interface's AddCommand method. These verbs are available for al elements.
Add verbs from plugin. The plugin can decide to add verbs based on current element or globally.
Add verbs using a designer. The element's designer (if one exists) can provide individual verbs for each object instance.
As you can see, adding verbs can be very flexible. Commands can appear permanently and globally, per element type, or per element instance. Verbs have specific properties to manage the appearance. The appearance itself depends on the hosts capabilities. The PropertyGrid for instance does not support the Checked property, whereas a context menu could support this and show a check sign accordingly. The NetRix implementation tries to apply these properties:
Checked *
Enabled
Visible
Supported *
* = Not supported by PropertyGrid
The properties does control the UI only, setting a the Enabled property to false does not prevent an object from calling the Invoke method and invoking the command. It's up to the host to prevent unwanted access to commands.

member.summary: DesignerHost creates the designer to add WebForms controls.
member.remarks: The designer host is responsible for all designer related tasks and design time features. Design time in the sense of this control means running the NetRix control in its "Design Mode" (compared with "Browse Mode"). NetRix provides a fully implemented design time environment at host applications runtime. The interfaces implemented by this class as well as several others form this environment. Components such as PropertyGrid are being able to use this by calling services (classes exposed as services are available through the ServiceProvider) or using reflection to indicate features added as attributes.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.Designer.ElementDesigner.Initialize(System.ComponentModel.IComponent)
member.summary: Called by internal designer host to initialize the designer.
member.exception: Thrown if the default event attribute is being used, but the exposed event did not exists.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.Designer.ElementDesigner.DoDefaultAction
member.summary: The default action for the component.
member.remarks:
The default event on an element causes this method to be called. Override this method to change the default behavior. In an application which behaves like Visual Studio a double click might open the code editor and add a event handler for the default event of the element.
The abstract base class, Element defines the attribute with the value "Click". This makes the click event the default event for any element. If one writes a new element class, which derives from Element or which implements IElement, the attribute could be overwritten with each other handler name.
To fully implement this behavior one must:
1. Add the DefaultEventAttribute to the component's class.
2. Override the DoDefaultAction method to receive the event at design time.
At design time, the user may issue the event by some action. Then the event manager receives the event and calles the attached handler, which in turn calles DoDefaultAction.
Important Note to implementors: Some events, like MouseMove, PropertyChange, or Resize are called very frequently and using these event in the scenario described above could slow the performance drastically. It's strongly recommended to use only events which have slow performance impact (so called single event actions). This is the case for events like Click, ResizeStart, ResizeEnd, MoveStart, MoveEnd, DblClick, MouseUp, MouseDown. It could be critical for key events and several mixed events, like those for drag 'n drop, for editing (cut/copy/paste) and selection.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding
member.summary: This class provides simplified access to the event binding management.
member.remarks:
If one is using the PropertyGrid to display properties and events, especially to create some kind of event driven editor, this class allows a finer grained control of the EventBinding behavior.
EventBindingService

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.EventDisplay
member.summary: Controls which events has to be displayed.
member.remarks: This property refers to the list of events available in the PropertyGrid once the events tab is shown. The list is build once the component is assigned to the PropertyGrid. The current value of this property controls the list, but subsequent changes of the property will not refresh the list.

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.ShowCodeRequest
member.summary: The user has double clicked the event name field in PropertyGrid and the editor is supposed to open the editor view and navigate to the handler code.

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.CreateUniqueNameRequest
member.summary: The user has double clicked the event name and before showing the code a unique name for the new event handler is required. If a name exists, this event did not fire again.

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.GetCompatibleMethodsRequest
member.summary: The user has clicked on the dropdown icon in PropertyGrid and expects to see a list of compatible methods (e.g. methods with the same signature).

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.EventSetValueRequest
member.summary: The PropertyGrid is up to set a new value, because the user has entered a new string. The editor is supposed to change the corresponding code.

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.EventGetValueRequest
member.summary: The PropertyGrid whishes to show the current values and the host is supposed to show the corresponding value.

member.name: E:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.EventBinding.EventResetValueRequest
member.summary: The value is getting reset and the handler informs the host to reset corresponding code accordingly.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeReplaceEventArgs
member.summary: This class defines data for the BeforeReplace event.
member.remarks: This class allows cancellation of replacement by setting the property.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeReplaceEventArgs.Result
member.summary: Sets the result of the handler.
member.remarks:
The various fields of the DialogResult enumeration have the following meaning:
YesReplace
OKReplace
NoneEnd method and stop all replacements (e.g. Cancel)
CancelEnd method and stop all replacements (e.g. Cancel)
AbortEnd method and stop all replacements (e.g. Cancel)
NoSkip this (current) replacement, but continue.
IgnoreSkip this (current) replacement, but continue.
RetryStart replacement at the beginning. (Helpful after some words were skipped)

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeReplaceEventArgs.Counter
member.summary: Returns the word counter result.
member.remarks: The number of words the Replace method has already replace or is about to replace, if the next action is allowed. The counter increases before the next word is replaced, but after the word is selected for replacement.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeReplaceEventHandler
member.summary: Fired if the control requests the next token for replacement.

member.summary: Set timeout used for this request.
member.remarks: Use this to reduce timeout for adserver and similar calls which are not required to be completely resolved.

member.summary: The Url passed to the event.

member.summary: The Url passed to the event, encoded.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeResourceLoadEventArgs.UrlTranslated
member.summary: Sets the translated version of the Url.
member.remarks: NetRix will load the source from the translated Url, if the host application changes the value. This will be ignored if cancel is set to true.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.Events.BeforeResourceLoadEventArgs.ResourceStream
member.summary: Resource stream used instead of the content of the URL.
member.remarks:
Within the event handler one might set the property to a stream and the loader will read the stream instead the URL. Set to null (Nothing in VB.NET) to assure the URL is read. This property is usually used to replace the content of objects like images from datasources other than files, for instance, accessing a database blob instead.
The stream is read from position 0 regardless the current pointer position. The stream is not closed but the position remains on the last byte after reading (this behavior is like the regular Read method call is behaving).

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.InsertComment(System.String)
member.summary: Inserts a HTML comment with the given text.
member.remarks: It is allowed to provide an empty string. Anyway, to access the comment later it is necessary to switch glyphs on and point the caret or cursor to the comment glyph. This will return the CommentElement object, which can be used to manipulate the content.
member.param: The text which is written into the comment.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.InsertHtml(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Insert HTML at caret position and delete any selected text, if the DeleteSelection parameter is true.
member.remarks: Inserting comments using this method is not possible. One should use InsertComment instead. This is due to limitations of the underlying MSHTML engine, that doesn't allow insertion of invisible elements using standard commands. This method inserts the given text as HTML, but it does not transform the DOM (Document Object Model) and does not add the inserted element to the current element hierarchy. If the element was previously created as a native object, any access to ElementDom will fail, as well as attaching behaviors and other internal operations with elements. The main usage of this method should be the insertion of entities (ñ   etc.) and inline HTML tags, to which further access doesn't make sense. For instance, in a text like "This is not allowed" the further access to the Bold tag is never necessary and building the structure using the DOM will simple raise the effort without any advantage.
member.param: HTML text to be inserted.
True, if the current selection should be deleted.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.InsertHtml(System.String)
member.summary: Inserts the specified string into the HTML over the current selection.
member.remarks: Inserting comments using this method is not possible. One should use InsertComment instead. This is due to limitations of the underlying MSHTML engine, that doesn't allow insertion of invisible elements using standard commands. This method inserts the given text as HTML, but it does not transform the DOM (Document Object Model) and does not add the inserted element to the current element hierarchy. If the element was previously created as a native object, any access to ElementDom will fail, as well as attaching behaviors and other internal operations with elements. The main usage of this method should be the insertion of entities (ñ   etc.) and inline HTML tags, to which further access doesn't make sense. For instance, in a text like "This is not allowed" the further access to the Bold tag is never necessary and building the structure using the DOM will simple raise the effort without any advantage.
member.exception: For inserting SCRIPT tags you must add the DEFER attribute. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/workshop/author/dhtml/reference/properties/innerhtml.asp for details.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.RemoveHyperlink
member.summary: Remove a hyperlink where the caret is placed in.
member.remarks: The text which the hyperlink contains will not be removed.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.WrapSelection(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new tag around the current HTML selection.
member.remarks: This method does not check for the validity of the new HTML. If the generated HTML is not valid the call causes unexpected results, including but not limited to ignoring the call.
member.param: The tag name which is used to build the tag, e.g. "DIV" for a division.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.WrapSelection(System.String,System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: Creates a new tag around the current HTML selection.
member.remarks: The textselection method used internally is "clever" in some ways and tries to keep the HTML valid and set the new element as expected. This can result in element duplication. This HTML stro[ngita]lic<, where [] covers the selected text range, would become strongitalic< after using the method with the tag SPAN. As you can see, the tag is duplicated to keep the HTML valid. After the selection has been changed, the method removes the selection and sets the caret to the end of range.
member.param: The tag name which is used to build the tag, e.g. "DIV" for a division.
A collection of attributes, expected as name/value pairs. Can be null (Nothing in VB.NET) if no attributes needed.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.ActivateNewElement

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.WrapSelectionInDiv
member.summary: Takes the selection and put an <div> around it.
member.remarks: The purpose of this method is to insert elements around selected text. If there is no selection the element will still be inserted, but it remains invisible if no styles are applied. The host application should be aware of inserting empty elements and should provide some help through the user interface to make such elements visible or reachable.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlDocument.Zoom
member.summary: Gets or set the editor window zoom level and persist it using body's zoom style attribute.
member.remarks:
This setting persist's by setting bod element's zoom style. In design mode, this zooms the scrollbars, too. In browse mode, the behavior of the scrollbars depends on the current DOCTYPE settings. To get desired behavior (content zoomed and scrollbars not zoomed, the following DOCTYPE setting is recommended:
<!doctype html public "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Strict//EN">
Insert this line as first line in each document to get desired zoom behavior.
member.value: Value for zoom, 1 equals 100%. Set 0.5 for 50% or 2.0 for 200%.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlSelection
member.summary: This class provides methods and properties for element selections and layer operations.
member.remarks: If the application provides absolute positioning various methods can be used to set z-order or align floating elements to the left, right or top. The class contains also method to wrap elements around the current selection. It doesn't matter if this selection is primarily a text or control selection.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlSelection.WrapSelection(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new tag around the current HTML selection.
member.remarks: This method does not check for the validity of the new HTML. If the generated HTML is not valid the call causes unexpected results.
member.param: The tag name which is used to build the tag, e.g. "DIV" for a division.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlSelection.WrapSelection(System.String,System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: Creates a new tag around the current HTML selection.
member.remarks: The textselection method used internally is "clever" in some ways and tries to keep the HTML valid and set the new element as expected. This can result in element duplication. This HTML stro[ngita]lic<, where [] covers the selected text range, would become strongitalic< after using the method with the tag SPAN. As you can see, the tag is duplicated to keep the HTML valid. After the selection has been changed, the method removes the selection and sets the caret to the end of range.
member.param: The tag name which is used to build the tag, e.g. "DIV" for a division.
A collection of attributes, expected as name/value pairs. Can be null (Nothing in VB.NET) if no attributes needed.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.HtmlSelection.RemoveCurrentElement(System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method removes the current element.
member.remarks: This method remove the current element (as shown in the property grid as result of the last HtmlElementChanged event). Normally this is where the caret is located. If the parameter preserveContent is true the content (text, child elements, …) is preserved. Removing an element will be reflected in the DOM immediately. Undo works as expected. Redo can throw an exception, if the removed element is added twice or more and the DOM does not allow this element to be nested at the current location. It is recommended to disable Redo after calling RemoveCurrentElement for at least one keystroke to avoid adding nested elements, which doesn’t make sense in HTML under most circumstances.
member.param: True if the content and children should not be deleted.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Networking.MhtBuilder
member.summary: This class provides support for creation of MHTML format files.
member.remarks:
MHTML stands for MIME HTML. It is a standard for including resources that in usual HTTP pages are linked externally, such as images and sound files, in the same file as the HTML code. The included data files are encoded using MIME. This format is sometimes referred to as MHT, after the suffix .mht given to such files by default when created by Microsoft Word, Internet Explorer or Opera.
The main idea of the MHTML standard is that you send a HTML document, together with in-line graphics, applets, etc., and also other linked documents if you so wish, in a MIME multipart/related body part. Links in the HTML to other included parts can be provided by CID (Content-ID) URLs or by any other kind of URI, and the linked body part is identified in its heading by either a Content-ID (linked to by CID URLs) or a Content-Location (linked to by any other kind of URL). (In fact, the "Content-ID: foo@bar header" can be seen as a special case of the "Content-Location: CID: foo@bar header".)
The Content-Location identifies a URI for a content part, the part need not be universally retrievable using this base.
The Content-Base identifies a base URI for a content, or for all objects within it which do not have their own Content-Base.
URIs in HTML-formatted messages and in Content-Location headers can be absolute and relative. If they are relative, and a base can be found, they are to be converted to absolute URIs before matching with other body parts. If no base can be found, then exact matching of the relative URIs in the HTML and the Content-Location of the linked parts is performed instead. The base can be found in a surrounding absolute Content-Location header.
Note: Before NetRix v1.6 the editor does not provide support for loading MHT documents.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.Networking.MhtBuilder.QuotedPrintable

summary.para: Robust and fast implementation of Quoted Printable Multipart Internet Mail Encoding (MIME) which encodes every character, not just "special characters" for transmission over SMTP.
More information on the quoted-printable encoding can be found here: http://www.freesoft.org/CIE/RFC/1521/6.htm

remarks.para: detailed in: RFC 1521
more info: http://www.freesoft.org/CIE/RFC/1521/6.htm

The QuotedPrintable class encodes and decodes strings and files that either were encoded or need encoded in the Quoted-Printable MIME encoding for Internet mail. The encoding methods of the class use pointers wherever possible to guarantee the fastest possible encoding times for any size file or string. The decoding methods use only the .NET framework classes.

The Quoted-Printable implementation is robust which means it encodes every character to ensure that the information is decoded properly regardless of machine or underlying operating system or protocol implementation. The decode can recognize robust encodings as well as minimal encodings that only encode special characters and any implementation in between. Internally, the class uses a regular expression replace pattern to decode a quoted- printable string or file.

member.name: F:GuruComponents.Netrix.Networking.MhtBuilder.QuotedPrintable.RFC_1521_MAX_CHARS_PER_LINE
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of characters per quoted-printable line as defined in the RFC minus 1 to allow for the = character (soft line break).
member.remarks: (Soft Line Breaks): The Quoted-Printable encoding REQUIRES that encoded lines be no more than 76 characters long. If longer lines are to be encoded with the Quoted-Printable encoding, 'soft' line breaks must be used. An equal sign as the last character on a encoded line indicates such a non-significant ('soft') line break in the encoded text.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.Networking.MhtBuilder.QuotedPrintable.Encode(System.String)
member.summary: Encodes a very large string into the Quoted-Printable encoding for transmission via SMTP
member.param: the very large string to encode
member.returns: The Quoted-Printable encoded string
member.exception: A problem occurred while attempting to read the encoded string.
There is insufficient memory to allocate a buffer for the returned string.
A string is passed in as a null reference.
An I/O error occurs, such as the stream being closed.
The charsperline argument is less than or equal to 0.
member.remarks: This method encodes a large string into the quoted-printable encoding and then properly formats it into lines of 76 characters using the method.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Behaviors.HtmlGrid.SnapZone
member.summary: Number of pixel the grid will snap.
member.remarks:
If the grid is every 20 pixels and the zone is 5, the snap feature will work from pixel 15 to 25 on first column. The pixel between 25 and 35 on second column will not snap. If the zone is equal or greater, then grid elements will always snap.
The default value is 4. If the default grid size is 8 x 8, the snap feature will snap anywhere, if it is active.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Behaviors.HtmlGrid.SnapOnResize
member.summary: Snap will also work on element resize.
member.remarks: The property applies, too.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Behaviors.SnapElement
member.summary: A helper class used internally that let elements snap to grid positions in absolute position mode.
member.remarks:
This class intercepts the drag event to snap elements to grid borders. Gridsize defaults to 8. That means, if you move an element in absolute position mode around the element "jumps" from one grid point to the next one. This function helps aligning elements properly.
This class is usually not used from custom code. To activate use the Grid's properties, such as SnapEnabled

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlDocumentStructure.GetElementCollection(System.String)
member.summary: Get a collection of elements from the given tag name.

remarks.para: For element type related operations this method retrieves a collection (ArrayList) of elements of a given tag name. This method is commonly used to add DHTML events to specific elements, and add wizards or dialogs to - for example - a double click.

The objects in the ArrayList are derived from IElement interface. They normally have their native base type, e.g. if one retrieves the collection of "A" tags the objects are from type . It is not recommended to change the expected base type. Even if it is working, it fails under some circumstances due to the different types of properties the elements provide. Returning the interface instead of a native class is a simplification to avoid the need of many getter methods for each type of element.

member.param: The tag name to be retrieved.
member.returns: The method returns null (Nothing in VB) if no such elements in the document.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlDocumentStructure.NamedMetaTags
member.summary: Get the current collection of META tags.

remarks.para: The getter is called by the propertygrid via reflection to determine the META tags and use events to propagate new values. The setter is only to use from the host application and set the complete collection at once. To add one value only just call the getter and then the Add() method.
To delete the whole list simply assign null: MetaCollection = null;. This will not destroy the object internally nor clear any resources, it will just call the Clear method.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlDocumentStructure.HttpEquivMetaTags
member.summary: Get the current collection of HTTP-EQUIV META tags.

remarks.para: The getter is called by the propertygrid via reflection to determine the META tags and use events to propagate new values. HTTP-EQUIV meta tags are modifiers for HTTP headers. The are often used to implement auto refresh or overwrite the default settings for charset or MIME type. The setter is only to use from the host application and set the complete collection at once. To add one value only just call the getter and then the Add() method.
To delete the whole list simply assign null: MetaCollection = null;. This will not destroy the object internally nor clear any resources, it will just call the Clear method.

The object is the same as used for named META tags. The both attributes used here (name="" and http-equiv="") are programmed in a toggle manner. This means that if the attribute name is set from hsot app the http-equiv parameter will set to String.Empty and vice versa.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlDocumentStructure.EmbeddedStylesheets
member.summary: This getter retrieves the collection of embedded stylesheets.
member.remarks: The property detects the style tags in the head section only.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlDocumentStructure.LinkedStylesheets
member.summary: This getter retrieves the collection of linked stylesheets.
member.remarks: It detects the stylesheets in link tags in a tolerant way, ether by checking the type attribute for "text/css" or the url in href attribute ends with ".css".

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlFrameSet
member.summary: HtmlFrameSet represents a complete framed master document.
member.remarks: This is the document containing one or more FrameSet tags. It returns a collection of FrameWindow objects which contain the complete frames, including all content and site management. It also contains a collection of HtmlFrameSet objects which represent frame documents which contain frames themself. This is a recursive strategy so there is no limit in handling nested frames. IFrameSet

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.GetElementFromPoint(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Returns the element for the specified x and y coordinates.
member.remarks:
Coordinates are supplied in client coordinates. The top left corner of the client area is (0,0). For this method to exhibit expected behavior, the element located at position (x, y) must support and respond to mouse events.
The parameter accepts values directly exposed by Mouse event handlers, such as MouseMove. There is no need to convert to Client as well as Screen coordinates or whatever.
If element was not found or not recognized, the method returns the Body element. However, it returns null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the element was unknow to the list of registered elements. This happens, for instance, for VML elements, which indeed render in MSHTML, but are not supported by NetRix v1. NetRix v2 and newer which have extensible element support will return the native element object, then.
member.param: X- and Y-offset, in pixels.
member.returns: Element for the specified x and y coordinates. Returns null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the element was unknow.

member.returns: Returns IElement object from caret.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.GetCaretLocation

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.FireScriptEvent(System.String,GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.IElement)
member.summary: Fires a specified script event on the given object.
member.remarks:
In difference to the fireEvent object the underlying IHTMLElement class provides it is always necessary to provide a valid object. The method call will fail if the element is not reletad to the current window or null (Nothing in Visual Basic).
If the event being fired cannot be cancelled, the method always returns true.
This method is available at runtime only. At design time it returns always true, but the event is not getting executed. To switch to runtime just set DesignModeEnabled to false. Remember to wait for OnReadyStateComplete event before executing script calls after changing the document mode.
The script code can be either JavaScript/JScript or VBScript.
Regardless of their values specified in the event object, the values of the four event properties—cancelBubble, returnValue, srcElement, and type—are automatically initialized to the values shown in the following table:
Event object property
Value
cancelBubblefalse
returnValuetrue
srcElementelement on which the event is fired
typename of the event that is fired

example.code: IElement element = htmlEditor1.GetElementById("button1"); bool success = FireScriptEvent("OnClick", element);

member.param: String that specifies the name of the event to fire.
Object that specifies the event object from which to obtain event object properties.
member.returns: Returns true if the event fired successfully.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.ExecScript(System.String)
member.summary: Executes the specified script in the provided language.
member.remarks:
Script executed through the IWindow.execScript method can access all global variables available to the calling script. This can be useful when you want the functionality of another scripting language that would not otherwise be available in JScript, such as the Microsoft Visual Basic Scripting Edition (VBScript) MsgBox function.
This method is available at runtime as well as at design time.
member.param: Value that specifies the code to be executed.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.ExecScript(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Executes the specified script in the provided language.
member.remarks:
Script executed through the IWindow.execScript method can access all global variables available to the calling script. This can be useful when you want the functionality of another scripting language that would not otherwise be available in JScript, such as the Microsoft Visual Basic Scripting Edition (VBScript) MsgBox function.
This method is available at runtime as well as at design time.
member.param: Value that specifies the code to be executed.
Value that specifies the language in which the code is executed. The language defaults to Microsoft JScript.
member.returns: Returns result of function execution.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.ShowWebPageDialog(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a modeless or modal dialog box that displays the specified HTML document.
member.remarks: See other overloads for additional information.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Documents.HtmlWindow.ShowWebPageDialog(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a modeless or modal dialog box that displays the specified HTML document.
member.remarks:
The unit used for the properties height, width, top and left is pixels. The property center will be ignoring the values for top and left to position the window in the screens center. The minimum height is 100 pixels, any smaller value will be ignored and set to at least 100. Despite that, the user can resize to smaller values if resizing is allowed.
This method fails, if the base document has no document loaded or the loaded document is from a different domain. That means, that the caller must assure that, if the base fileName property points to a local file, the base document must have a local document loaded.
If the dialog is non-modal, it stays still always on top of the host application. The method can be called multiple times to produce multiple windows, which exists independently from each other.
If the document contains links with targets other than _self, a new Internet Explorer window will open to follow the link. This window does not have any conjunction with the host application and can therefore not being controlled from NetRix. To avoid this, carefully set the target="_self" attribute for all links. Remember, that the dialog opened cannot be controlled from NetRix and therefore does not provide any editing capabilities nor fires any events.
The title of the dialog box is always the content of the title tag and the string "-- Web Page Dialog". This behavior cannot be changed. The dialog has no select, drag 'n drop and other mouse related features.
member.param: Specifies the URL of the document to load and display.
If false, creates a modeless dialog box that displays the specified HTML document. If true, creates a modal dialog box that displays the specified HTML document.
Sets the height of the dialog window (see Remarks for default unit of measure).
Sets the width of the dialog window (see Remarks for default unit of measure).
Sets the top position of the dialog window relative to the upper-left corner of the desktop.
Sets the left position of the dialog window relative to the upper-left corner of the desktop.
Specifies whether to center the dialog window within the desktop. The default is true.
Specifies whether the dialog window is hidden when printing or using print preview.
Specifies the edge style of the dialog window. The value false is raised.
Specifies whether the dialog window displays the context-sensitive Help icon.
Specifies whether the dialog window has fixed dimensions.
Specifies whether the dialog window displays scrollbars.
Specifies whether the dialog window displays a status bar.
Specifies whether the dialog window displays the border window chrome.

member.summary: A base class used to support the NetRix infrastructure.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.accessKey
member.summary: The ACCESSKEY attribute.
member.remarks: By default, the accessKey property sets focus to the object. The object receives focus when the user simultaneously presses the ALT key and the accelerator key assigned to an object. Some controls perform an action after receiving focus. For example, using accessKey on a input type=button causes the onclick event to fire. By comparison, applying the accessKey on a radio button causes the onclick event to fire and toggles the checked property, visibly selecting or deselecting the control.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.disabled
member.summary: The DISABLED attribute, disables the element.
member.remarks:
The most elements are drawn grayed or with a gray shadow to inform the user that the element is disabled. Field elements do not except the focus and do not display the caret.
In HTML the element is disables if the attribute exists and it is enabled if it doesn't exist. The parameter assigned to the attribute is useless.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.hideFocus
member.summary: Sets or retrieves the value indicating whether the object visibly indicates that it has focus.
member.remarks: The focus of an object is visibly indicated by a focus rectangle—a dotted rectangle within the boundaries of the object. This property does not control the ability of an object to receive focus; for that, use the tabIndex property.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.ScriptOnFocus
member.summary: Defines an client site event which is fired if the element receives the focus.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.ScriptOnKeyPress
member.summary: Defines an client site event which is fired if the element registered a key stroke.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.SelectableElement.tabIndex
member.summary: Gets or set the TAB index.
member.remarks:
If the user hits the TAB key the focus moves from block element to block element, beginning with the first element on a page. To change the default TAB chain the tabIndex can be set to any numeric (integer) value which force the order of the TAB key. The value must be greater or equal than 0 (zero).
To remove the attribute set the value to 0 (zero).

member.summary: HREF indicates the URL being linked to.
member.remarks: HREF makes the anchor into a link.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.AreaElement.nohref
member.summary: Indicates that this area is not a link.
member.remarks: NOHREF indicates that the AREA is not a link. Of course, NOHREF doesn't make much sense unless the area is in a map that uses <AREA SHAPE=DEFAULT> or the area overlies another area that does have an HREF. For example, suppose we wanted an image map in which a circle in the map is a link, but a smaller circle inside the link circle is not a link. We could accomplish that by first putting the tag for the inner area (earlier <AREA ...> tags overlay later <AREA ...> tags), and using the NOHREF atribute, then putting the tag for the outer <AREA ...>:

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.AreaElement.alt
member.summary: Use as alt="text" attribute.
member.remarks: For user agents that cannot display images, forms, or applets, this attribute specifies alternate text. The language of the alternate text is specified by the lang attribute.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.AreaElement.coords
member.summary: Coordinates for the link area shape.
member.remarks:
COORDS indicates whare the shape is located in the image map. COORDS is necessary if you set SHAPE to RECT, CIRCLE, or POLY. COORDS is not required if you set SHAPE to DEFAULT.
Coordinates are always entered as a comma delimited string of numbers. That is, the stirng consists of a number, then a comma, then another number, then a comma, etc. Don’t put a comma after the last number. The exact meaning of those list of numbers is different for each shape, so see the descriptions of the values for the SHAPE attribute for details.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.AreaElement.shape
member.summary: The shap which creates the sensitive area.
member.remarks: See for more details.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BdoElement
member.summary: BDO overrides the current direction information.
member.remarks:
The BDO element is a directional override feature needed to deal with unusual pieces of text in which directionality cannot be resolved from context in an unambiguous fashion. It requires the DIR attribute. The meaning of DIR is different on BDO than on inline text markup elements. For BDO the DIR attribute is a bidi override, forcing the directionnality of even those characters that have strong directionnality. On inline elements, DIR indicates a new directional embedding level, affecting mostly the neutrals and the overall layout.
To insert BDO elements just use InsertBidirectionalOverride.
Another way to deal woth text direction features is the usage of the direct formatting features, which applies to text selection or - in case of of paragraphs - whole paragraphs. For more information about this topic see DirectionRtlBlock, DirectionRtlInline, and DirectionRtlDocument. The BDO element is used to format inline only.
DirectionRtlInline

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BlockquoteElement
member.summary: The BLOCKQUOTE tag defines the start of a long quotation.
member.remarks:
The BLOCKQUOTE tag is supposed to contain only block-level elements within it, and not just plain text. To validate the page as strict XHTML, you must add a block-level element around the text within the BLOCKQUOTE tag, like this:

here is a long quotation here is a long quotation

The blockquote element creates white space on both sides of the text

member.remarks: BODY is required in non-frames documents, but its start and end tags are always optional. In frames documents, BODY must be contained within the NOFRAMES element, if NOFRAMES is used.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.#ctor(GuruComponents.Netrix.IHtmlEditor)
member.summary: Creates the specified element.
member.remarks:
The element is being created and attached to the current document, but nevertheless not visible, until it's being placed anywhere within the DOM. To attach an element it's possible to either use the property of any other already placed element and refer to this DOM or use the body element () and add the element there. Also, in case of user interactive solutions, it's possible to add an element near the current caret position, using method.
Note: Invisible elements do neither appear in the DOM nor do they get saved.
member.param: The editor this element belongs to.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.title
member.summary: Hide the inherited member. Not used.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.aLink
member.summary: ALINK suggests an active link color.
member.remarks: Active means the link is selected by user. It is recommended to use style sheets (CSS) instead.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.bgProperties
member.summary: BGPROPERTIES defines the behavior of a background image.
member.remarks: This attribute is not HTML 4.0 conform and is recognized by MSIE only. It is not recommended to use this property. BackgroundPropertyType

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.background
member.summary: The BACKGROUND attribute suggests a background image for tiling on the document canvas.
member.remarks: To help ensure a readable document, the bgColor, text, link, vLink, and aLink attributes should always be included when BACKGROUND is given. The BGCOLOR will be used for those not loading images.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.bgColor
member.summary: BGCOLOR suggests a background color.
member.remarks: If the BACKGROUND attribute is set and the images is available this attribute is not recognized. background

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.bottomMargin
member.summary: Set the BOTTOMMARGIN attribute.
member.remarks: The attribute sets the margin at the bottom of the page. This attribute defaults to 15 pixels. To remove the attribute completely set the value to -1.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.leftMargin
member.summary: Set the LEFTMARGIN attribute.
member.remarks: The attribute sets the margin at the left side of the page. This attribute defaults to 10 pixels. To remove the attribute completely set the value to -1.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.link
member.summary: LINK suggests a link color.
member.remarks: This value can be overwritten by style sheets. It applies to ANCHOR tags only.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.rightMargin
member.summary: Set the RIGHTMARGIN attribute.
member.remarks: The attribute sets the margin at the right side of the page. This attribute defaults to 10 pixels. To remove the attribute completely set the value to -1.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.text
member.summary: TEXT suggests a text color.
member.remarks: It is recommended to use style sheets (CSS) instead of setting this attribute to a static color.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.topMargin
member.summary: Set the TOPMARGIN attribute.
member.remarks: The attribute sets the margin at the top of the page. This attribute defaults to 15 pixels. To remove the attribute completely set the value to -1.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BodyElement.vLink
member.summary: VLINK suggests a visited link color.
member.remarks: The visited link table is stored in the browser. The time the links remains as visited cannot be controlled by server application. Therefore the behavior is not predictable nor reliable.

member.remarks: In most cases, use of a phrase element such as STRONG is more appropriate since such elements express the meaning of the text more clearly.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BreakElement
member.summary: The BR element forces a break in the current line of text.
member.remarks: BR can be useful in formatting addresses within the ADDRESS element, but it is often misused to break lines of text in a paragraph or table cell when it looks "nice" to the author. This usually results in an awkward presentation when viewed with a font size other than that used by the author. ParagraphElement

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.BreakElement.clear
member.summary: The CLEAR attribute of BR is used to move below floating objects.
member.remarks:
Floating objects are typically images or tables. In the following example, the second paragraph should be rendered below the floating image:

Toronto is the largest city in Canada and the fourth largest in North America.


The city is highly multicultural, with over 80 ethnic communities from Africa, Asia, and Europe...

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.CenterElement
member.summary: The CENTER element defines a block whose contents are centered horizontally on visual browsers.
member.remarks:
<CENTER> is a shorthand for <DIV ALIGN=center>, though CENTER is slightly better supported among browsers. Both methods of centering are deprecated in favor of style sheets (CSS).
If you setup a user interface it is recommended to use <div style="text-align:center"> to center any text in a container. This class is available to get backwards compatibility with elder HTML pages edited with NetRix.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DefinitionListDefinitionElement
member.summary: The DL element defines a definition list.
member.remarks:
An entry in the list is created using the DT element for the term being defined and the DD element for the definition of the term.
A definition list can have multiple terms for a given definition as well as multiple definitions for a given term. Authors can also give a term without a corresponding definition, and vice versa, but such a structure rarely makes sense.

member.summary: The DD element provides the definition of a term in a definition list.
member.remarks: The closing tag for DD is optional, but its use prevents common browser bugs with style sheets.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DefinitionListTermElement
member.summary: The DT element defines a term in a definition list.
member.remarks:
The closing tag for DT is optional, but its use prevents common browser bugs with style sheets. Note that DT cannot contain block-level elements such as P and H2.
A DT element should generally be followed by a DD element that provides the definition for the term given by the DT. A single definition term may have multiple definitions associated with it, and a single definition may have multiple terms.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DeletedElement
member.summary: The DEL element contains content that has been deleted.
member.remarks:
This element is useful in marking changes from one version of a document to the next. Through style sheets, authors can suggest an appropriate rendering, such as not displaying the deleted content or rendering the text with a strike-through style.
DEL may be used as either a block-level element or an inline element. If used as an inline element (e.g., within a P), then DEL may not contain any block-level elements.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DeletedElement.cite
member.summary: The CITE attribute of DEL gives a URI with information on why the content was deleted. Optional.
member.remarks: A brief explanation for the deletion can be given with the TITLE attribute, which may be rendered as a "tooltip" by some browsers.

member.name: P:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DeletedElement.datetime
member.summary: The optional DATETIME attribute specifies the date and time of the deletion.
member.remarks:
The value is case-sensitive and of the form YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssTZD. See the values section for a full explanation of this format. The usage is shown by the following example:

The XMP element contains preformatted text in which markup other than an end tag is treated as literal text.

Since DEL is poorly supported among browsers, authors may wish to use a font style element such as STRIKE (deprecated in HTML 4.0) to attempt to convey the meaning of DEL to non-supporting visual browsers.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.DirectoryElement
member.summary: The DIR element defines a directory list.
member.remarks:
The element contains one or more LI elements that define the actual items of the list. The LI elements must not contain block-level elements, which prevents DIRs from being nested.
DIR is deprecated in HTML 4.0 in favor of UL.

member.summary: Disables the element.
member.remarks:
The most elements are drawn grayed or with a gray shadow to inform the user that the element is disabled. Field elements do not except the focus and do not display the caret.
In HTML the element is disables if the attribute exists and it is enabled if it doesn't exist. The parameter assigned to the attribute is useless.

member.summary: This class allows access to additional positioning information.
member.remarks:

The positions are in pixel and relative to the control window.

member.name: T:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties
member.summary: This class allows access to additional information about an element and advanced element manipulation.
member.remarks:
This class enhances the basic Element class. It was introduced to avoid the ability of non-HTML attributes for propertygrid access. The ScrollXX properties allow the detection of the current scroll position to synchronize external controls like ruler or bars.
The positions are in pixel and relative to the control window.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.#ctor(GuruComponents.Netrix.ComInterop.Interop.IHTMLElement)
member.summary: Constructor to create an instance of the class.
member.remarks: THIS CTOR SUPPORTS THE NETRIX INFRASTRUCTURE AND IS NIT INTENDET TO BEING USED FROM USER CODE.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.DoScroll(GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ScrollAction)
member.summary: Simulates a click on a scroll-bar component.
member.remarks:
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) allow you to scroll on all objects through the IHTMLStyle::overflow property.
When the content of an element changes and causes scroll bars to display, the IHTMLElement2::doScroll method might not work correctly immediately following the content update. When this happens, you can use the IHTMLWindow2::setTimeout method to enable the browser to recognize the dynamic changes that affect scrolling.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.ComponentFromPoint(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Returns the component located at the specified coordinates via certain events.
member.remarks:
A component is a part of the element, which acts as an specific interaction point. Typically these are the scrollbars as well as parts of the scrollbar, and the resizing handles. The property can be used to determine such an element at a specific client location.
The ComponentFromPoint method, available as of MSHTML 5, is applicable to any object that can be given scroll bars through Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).
The ComponentFromPoint method may not consistently return the same object when used with the MouseOver event. Because a user's mouse speed and entry point can vary, different components of an element can fire the MouseOver event. For example, when a user moves the cursor over a AreaElement object with scroll bars, the event might fire when the mouse enters the component border, the scroll bars, or the client region. Once the event fires, the expected element may not be returned unless the scroll bars were the point of entry for the mouse. In this case, the onmousemove event can be used to provide more consistent results.
A good idea to get the current handle is the ResizeStart event, which is fired when the mouse is on top of one of the handles of an selected element. However, this will never return components other than "HandleXX" or nothing.
member.param: Location in client coordinates of the point for which the component is retrieved.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.Normalize
member.summary: Merges adjacent objects to produce a normalized document object model.
member.remarks: Calling Normalize before manipulating the subelements of an object ensures that the document object model has a consistent structure. The normal form is useful for operations that require a consistent document tree structure, and it ensures that the document object model view is identical when saved and reloaded.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.ScrollIntoView
member.summary: Causes the object to scroll into view, aligning at the top of the window.
member.remarks:
The ScrollIntoView method is useful for immediately showing the user the result of some action without requiring the user to manually scroll through the document to find the result.
Depending on the size of the given object and the current window, this method might not be able to put the item at the very top or very bottom, but will position the object as close to the requested position as possible.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.ScrollIntoView(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Causes the object to scroll into view, aligning it either at the top or bottom of the window.
member.remarks:
The ScrollIntoView method is useful for immediately showing the user the result of some action without requiring the user to manually scroll through the document to find the result.
Depending on the size of the given object and the current window, this method might not be able to put the item at the very top or very bottom, but will position the object as close to the requested position as possible.
member.param: Specifies where to scroll to. If true the element is scrolled to top position.

member.name: M:GuruComponents.Netrix.WebEditing.Elements.ExtendedProperties.ReleaseCapture
